title: Huckabee Opposes Elimination Of Funding For National Endowment For The Arts
text:
Huckabee Opposes Elimination Of Funding For National Endowment For The Arts "... test-drive their God-given creativity ..." Share on Facebook 391 Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
Despite former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee’s known advocacy for smaller government, he believes one federal agency that would lose funding under the Trump administration’s new budget proposal deserves a second look. 
In an op-ed published in The Washington Post, Huckabee, identified also as an “amateur musician,” states the case for sparing the National Endowment for the Arts from the budget axe. 
“No doubt a chainsaw seems more appropriate to the task at hand than a carving knife, but I would urge my president and friend to hold back from one tiny area of the budget whose elimination would cost far more than it would save,” Huckabee wrote. Advertisement - story continues below Conservative Congressman Says Passing Healthcare Bill Will Doom Trump In 2020 
He then sought to distinguish between the elite Hollywood stars who trash President Donald Trump and the deserving recipients served by the NEA. 
“I have zero interest in spending a dime of tax money to prop up those who hate the president and the tens of millions who elected him,” he wrote. 
“I do care greatly about the real recipients of endowment funds: the kids in poverty for whom NEA programs may be their only chance to learn to play an instrument, test-drive their God-given creativity and develop a passion for those things that civilize and humanize us all,” he wrote, citing a figure that the NEA’s funding is only .004 percent of federal spending. Advertisement - story continues below 
Huckabee also defended his support of the NEA on Twitter. @mikestill It isn't about whether they "like" the President. It's about the kids like me who grew up poor, but deserve access to music. 
— Gov. Mike Huckabee (@GovMikeHuckabee) March 23, 2017 @dwhfarmall That kind of crap ended in the 90's when Newt led the GOP budget. That is NOT what is funded now. Please read my full column 
— Gov. Mike Huckabee (@GovMikeHuckabee) March 23, 2017 
In his column, Huckabee marshaled two main arguments in favor of the NEA. He contended that arts are not an extra, but an essential in the lives of young people. Advertisement - story continues below Schumer Claims FBI’s Russian Probe Requires Delay In Vote On Gorsuch 
“Music and art deliver, especially for students likely to get lost in an education assembly line that can be more Pink Floyd’s Another Brick in the Wall than about creative thinking and problem solving,” he wrote, citing research that linked arts involvement with high academic achievement. “Creativity finds cures for diseases, creates companies such as Apple and Microsoft and, above all, makes our culture more livable.” 
He also noted that the NEA has moved away from supporting often-controversial individual artists and has revised its funding formula requiring communities to match the federal investment. Huckabee said 40 percent of the NEA’s funding goes to states and communities that then select the local artists. 
“Many children get their only access to music and the arts via grants made by the NEA — 40 percent of which go to high-poverty neighborhoods, while 36 percent reach underserved people, such as veterans and those with disabilities,” he wrote. 
Huckabee said there is a difference between NEA funding and government waste. 
“I truly want the government to stop wasting my tax money. I want it to stop funding things that don’t work and things that get funded only because they are some congressman’s pet project or have a powerful lobby behind them. To some, it may seem as though the $147.9 million allocated to the NEA in fiscal 2016 is money to be saved,” he wrote. “But to someone such as me — for whom an early interest in music and the arts became a lifeline to an education and academic success — this money is not expendable, extracurricular or extraneous. It is essential.” 
“I’m for cutting waste and killing worthless programs. I’m not for cutting and killing the hope and help that come from creativity,” he added. What do you think? Scroll down to comment below. Suggest a correction Share on Facebook 391 Tweet Email Email Print Popular Right Now
